name: Agent MIS aliment√© par l'IA

user.name: Kumar Shivam
user.bio:
I'm an automation specialist who helps startups, agencies, and growth teams save time and scale faster using n8n.

I design smart, reliable workflows that connect tools like HubSpot, Slack, OpenAI, Claude, Pipedrive, Google Ads, and vector databases (Qdrant, Pinecone). Whether it's auto-assigning leads, generating AI-powered reports, triggering Slack alerts, or syncing APIs ‚Äî I build automations that just work.
Let‚Äôs turn your manual processes into automated systems that scale.

description:
L'agent MIS aliment√© par l'IA est un syst√®me intelligent et automatis√© construit avec n8n qui rationalise la collecte de donn√©es par e-mail et l'organisation de documents pour les entreprises. Il classe les e-mails entrants, extrait et traite les pi√®ces jointes ou les liens Drive, et les achemine vers les bons dossiers de destination dans Google Drive. De plus, il fournit des op√©rations avanc√©es sur les fichiers telles que le nettoyage, la fusion, la jointure et la transformation des donn√©es.

### Avantages
üì• Gestion automatis√©e des e-mails et des fichiers
D√©tecte et traite les e-mails contenant des pi√®ces jointes ou des liens Drive, garantissant une classification et un acheminement sans faille des fichiers critiques pour l'entreprise.

### üß† Classification bas√©e sur l'IA
Utilise des LLM (comme GPT-4o Mini) pour classer les e-mails en cat√©gories telles que Ventes quotidiennes, Informations clients et Adresses en fonction de leur contenu.
### üìÇ Acheminement et t√©l√©chargement de fichiers intelligents
Reconna√Æt si un fichier est une pi√®ce jointe directe ou un lien Google Drive, extrait l'ID du fichier si n√©cessaire et le t√©l√©charge dans des dossiers pr√©d√©finis.
### üìä Op√©rations de donn√©es puissantes
Prend en charge des op√©rations telles que l'ajout, la jointure, le regroupement, l'agr√©gation et la normalisation des donn√©es directement √† partir de feuilles de calcul en utilisant Python et Pandas dans le flux de travail.

### üîÅ Automatisation planifi√©e et d√©clench√©e
Prend en charge les ex√©cutions planifi√©es et les d√©clencheurs d'e-mails en temps r√©el, ce qui le rend tr√®s fiable et opportun.

### üîß Enti√®rement modulaire et √©volutif
Facilement extensible avec plus de logique, de nouveaux dossiers ou diff√©rents flux de travail. Une architecture propre et des annotations rendent la maintenance simple.

### Comment √ßa fonctionne
#### D√©clencheur d'e-mail
Le syst√®me utilise un d√©clencheur Gmail pour surveiller les e-mails entrants avec des √©tiquettes ou des pi√®ces jointes sp√©cifiques.

#### Classification
Un classificateur de texte bas√© sur LLM identifie l'objectif de l'e-mail (par exemple, donn√©es de vente, liste d'adresses, d√©tails clients).

#### Logique conditionnelle
Des conditions bas√©es sur des expressions r√©guli√®res v√©rifient si l'e-mail contient des liens Google Drive ou des pi√®ces jointes.

#### Gestion des fichiers
S'il s'agit d'un lien Drive, il extrait l'ID du fichier et le copie dans le bon dossier. S'il s'agit d'une pi√®ce jointe, il le t√©l√©charge directement.

#### Gestion des donn√©es planifi√©e
D√©place ou enregistre p√©riodiquement des fichiers √† partir de dossiers pr√©d√©finis en utilisant un d√©clencheur de planification.

#### Nettoyage et traitement des donn√©es
Effectue des t√¢ches de nettoyage et de transformation des donn√©es telles que le remplacement des valeurs manquantes, la normalisation des formats et la jointure des ensembles de donn√©es en fonction des crit√®res fournis par l'utilisateur.

#### Sortie finale
Les fichiers nettoy√©s et trait√©s sont enregistr√©s dans des dossiers d√©sign√©s avec leurs liens publics partag√©s √† nouveau via le syst√®me.

### √âtapes de configuration
Configurer les n≈ìuds :
D√©clencheur Gmail : D√©tecte les e-mails entrants pertinents.

- Classificateur de texte : Utilise le mod√®le OpenAI pour cat√©goriser le contenu des e-mails.

- Conditions Regex : D√©termine si un lien ou une pi√®ce jointe est pr√©sent.

- Op√©rations Google Drive : T√©l√©charge ou copie des fichiers dans des dossiers cat√©goris√©s.

- N≈ìuds Python : G√®re la manipulation des donn√©es en utilisant Pandas.

- N≈ìuds Google Sheets : Extrait, nettoie et √©crit des donn√©es structur√©es.

- Mod√®les de chat bas√©s sur LLM : Extrait et applique des configurations de nettoyage.

### Connecter les n≈ìuds :
- Connectez sans effort les entr√©es Gmail, la classification, le traitement des fichiers et la logique des donn√©es.

- Les liens de sortie ou les fichiers trait√©s sont t√©l√©charg√©s √† nouveau sur Drive et pr√™ts √† √™tre partag√©s.

- Identifiants :
 Assurez-vous que les identifiants OAuth pour Gmail, Google 
 Drive et OpenAI sont correctement configur√©s.

 ### Id√©al pour
- √âquipes de vente et de CRM g√©rant de grands volumes de rapports par e-mail.

- √âquipes de donn√©es ayant besoin de pipelines structur√©s √† partir d'entr√©es d'e-mails non structur√©es.

- Entreprises cherchant √† automatiser la classification, le stockage et la transformation des donn√©es routini√®res.

### Tests et personnalisation suppl√©mentaire

- Si vous souhaitez tester cette capacit√© de bot 
  avant d'acheter le flux de travail.
  contactez-moi par mail 
  kumar.shivam19oce@gmail.com
  Je partagerai l'URL de chat et les liens des 
  Google Drives associ√©s pour voir le r√©sultat
  une fois que vous serez satisfait, nous pourrons 
  proc√©der.
  J'ai juste fix√© 1 $ √† des fins de test 
  en raison de l'IA ouverte payante.
  

 -Si une personnalisation est n√©cessaire, comme des graphiques et d'autres demandes comme l'ajout de bases de donn√©es, n'h√©sitez pas √† me le faire savoir, je peux le faire en cons√©quence.

- C'est la premi√®re version, je viendrai avec plus d'avanc√©es en fonction des demandes et des r√©ponses.


### Utilisez-le et faites-le moi savoir √† kumar.shivam19oce@gmail.com

data.details:
The IF node can be used to implement binary conditional logic in your workflow. You can set up one-to-many conditions to evaluate each item of data being inputted into the node. That data will either evaluate to TRUE or FALSE and route out of the node accordingly.

This node has multiple types of conditions: Bool, String, Number, and Date & Time.

* Whenever a specific mail hits your inbox

* You can set the trigger as it suits you

parameters.pythonCode:
import pandas as pd 

# Step 1: Extract join configuration
join_type = _input.all()[0]['json']['Join_criteria']['join_type'].lower()
left = _input.all()[0]['json']['Join_criteria']['left_on']
right = _input.all()[0]['json']['Join_criteria']['right_on']
in_len1 = _input.all()[0]['json']['len_input_1']
in_len2 = _input.all()[-1]['json']['len_input_2']

# Step 2: Build df1 and df2
data = [item['json'] for item in _input.all()]
df1 = pd.DataFrame(data)[:in_len1]
df2 = pd.DataFrame(data)[in_len1:]

# Step 3: Drop helper/meta columns
meta_cols = ['Join_criteria', 'len_input_1', 'len_input_2']
df1 = df1.drop(columns=[col for col in meta_cols if col in df1.columns], errors='ignore')
df2 = df2.drop(columns=[col for col in meta_cols if col in df2.columns], errors='ignore')

# Step 4: Drop rows from df2 where 'uni_key' is null
df2 = df2.dropna(subset=[right])


# Step 5: Identify common columns
common_cols = set(df1.columns).intersection(df2.columns) - {left,right}

# Step 6: Drop columns in df1 that are null and match df2
cols_to_drop_from_df1 = [col for col in common_cols if df1[col].isna().all()]
df1 = df1.drop(columns=cols_to_drop_from_df1)

# Step 7: Drop columns in df2 that are null and match df1
cols_to_drop_from_df2 = [col for col in common_cols if df2[col].isna().all()]
df2 = df2.drop(columns=cols_to_drop_from_df2)

# Step 8: Perform join or append
if join_type == 'append':
    result_df = pd.concat([df1, df2], ignore_index=True)
elif join_type in ('inner', 'left', 'right'):
    result_df = pd.merge(df1, df2, how=join_type, left_on=left, right_on=right)

# Step 9: Return formatted result
output = result_df.to_dict(orient="records")
return [{ "json": row } for row in output]

import pandas as pd

# Only handle append case with duplicate removal based on left_on key

# Extract key for duplicate removal (left_on)
left_on = _input.all()[0]['json']['Join_criteria'].get('left_on')

# Get input lengths
in_len1 = _input.all()[0]['json']['len_input_1']
#in_len2 = _input.all()[0]['json']['len_input_2']

# Get all data
data = [item['json'] for item in _input.all()]

# Split dataframes
df1 = pd.DataFrame(data)[:in_len1]
df2 = pd.DataFrame(data)[in_len1:]

# Drop meta columns if present
meta_cols = ['Join_criteria', 'len_input_1', 'len_input_2']
df1 = df1.drop(columns=[col for col in meta_cols if col in df1.columns], errors='ignore')
df2 = df2.drop(columns=[col for col in meta_cols if col in df2.columns], errors='ignore')

# Append dataframes
result_df = pd.concat([df1, df2], ignore_index=True)

# Remove duplicates if left_on key is provided and exists in df
if left_on and left_on in result_df.columns:
    result_df = result_df.drop_duplicates(subset=[left_on], keep='last')

# Return results
output = result_df.to_dict(orient="records")
return [{"json": row} for row in output]

parameters.content:
## Data Cleaning/Transformation


* clean /replace missing values
* Fetch Data type
* Change Data type
* Replace any value
* gives clean file at the end in the drive
* link to that file will be given by the agent.

# Using the AI-Powered MIS Agent Workflow  



1. Deploy the supplied JSON workflow in n8n and switch it **Active**.  
2. Copy the public URL from the **Chat Trigger** node.  
3. POST a body like `{"query":"your request"}` to that URL to talk to the agent or use webhook to connect your chatbot.  
4. The agent‚Äôs **Text Classifier** detects intent: fetch, clean, summarize, join, etc.  
5. Always mention the exact Google-Sheet name; add its webViewLink if uncertain.  
6. Ask ‚Äútop 10 rows of Daily Sales‚Äù to preview data without edits.  
7. Say ‚Äúgroup by Region, sum Total Sales in Master‚Äù for summaries.  
8. Say ‚Äúleft-join Master and customer_info on uni_key‚Äù for joins.  
9. For cleaning, specify column and action: ‚Äúreplace 1‚Üí2 in Rating of Master‚Äù.  
10. The agent builds a validated JSON payload for the **Information Extractor**.  
11. Python/Sheets nodes then execute the required transformation live.  
12. Results save to Drive; the agent replies with the new file‚Äôs link.  
13. If `fetch_type` is requested, inferred column data types are displayed first.  
14. All outputs are also logged to the **n8n_logs** Drive folder for audit.  
15. Missing links trigger a polite prompt to supply or correct the file info.  
16. Edit the *Drive Folders URL* Set node to match your own Drive folder IDs.  
17. Extend capabilities by cloning Code nodes and updating classifier labels.  
18. Pause the workflow when idle to conserve OpenAI token usage.  
19. Reach out via chat any time‚Äîevery operation is conversationally driven.  
20. The bot can sometimes hallucinates but it recorrects it's mistakes if asked if it is unclear  make it understand.
21. Not all the task here is done by ai agent. I have used the Ai agent to use for routing and text parsing ability to perform task where hardcoded steps are better and accurate.
22. You can replace the default Google Sheet links with your own ‚Äî edit them in the "fetch_file" and "memory_store" sheets or configure in the Google Sheets node.

23.Update the Google Drive Upload and Google Drive Logs nodes with your personal or company Drive folder IDs for saving results.

24. Adjust the Google Sheets API credentials in your n8n settings (OAuth2 or service account).

25. If using your own OpenAI key, change the API Key in the OpenAI node environment variable or credentials section.
26. To test if it's working replace your drive links wherever it is necessary.
27. I have standardised the sheet name in google spreadsheet with name 'raw_data' to check it's functioning. you can make the changes but it is advisable to change all the  spreadsheet sheet
name with a common name. 
28. Knowledge base has been given if your organisation or work require specific kind of sops or formulae you can add the vector store as a tool to enable the bot to answer user specific queries. but you have to change the system prompt accordingly.
29. you can add the databases if you want.
30. I can add the charting capability on demand as well as other custom demands.

## Structured Json  
* sends formatted json instructions to the code block along with spreadsheet link

## Structured Json  
* sends formatted json instructions to the code block along with spreadsheet link

## Convert The cleaned file into Csv  and Upload to Google Drive


* Final set node is accessing the weblink and name of file generated after the upload which is used as response for the user to access the file from chat interface

## Convert The Merge Operation into Csv  and Upload to Google Drive


* Final set node is accessing the weblink and name of file generated after the upload which is used as response for the user to access the file from chat interface

## This node only returns the fetched data types 
no storing required into drive


* Fetched data dtypes goes to the bot and returned on the chat interface as a response

## Merge Operation using Python


* Upper code node is doing inner,left,outer join
* lower code node is used to append the two data inputs

##  Cleaning Operation using Python


* Upper code node is doing inner,left,outer join
* lower code node is used to append the two data inputs

categories.description: The text or json will contain Join
it will contain the request to fetch weblink or fetch file name
I t will contain the keywords clean transform or fetch type

options.systemPromptTemplate:
=You will receive a string (plain text, HTML, or JSON) describing a spreadsheet join operation.

Your task is to extract and return a JSON object with the following structure:

"operation": must be "Join"

"Join_criteria": object with:

"join_type": one of "left", "right", "inner", "outer", "append"

"left_on": join key from the left table (string)

"right_on": join key from the right table (string)

"Left_table_name": name of the left table (string)

"left_web_link": Google Sheet link for the left table (string)

"right_table_name": name of the right table (string)

"right_web_link": Google Sheet link for the right table (string)

Rules:
If valid JSON input is found, validate and clean it:

"operation" must be "Join" 

All fields must be non-empty strings.

"join_type" must be one of: "left", "right", "inner", "outer", "append"

Both web links must be valid Google Sheets URLs.

If the input is plain text:

Identify join intent (join, merge, combine, append)

Extract table names, join type, join columns, and links.

Build and return the correct JSON structure.

parameters.content:
## Merge all the Links IDs and Name of files

* Sends the merged infos of all files in the folders to the MIS Agent and agent returns this output to the user on the chat interface.

parameters.description: Call this tool to fetch the data from the work flow.

options.systemMessage:
=You are a polite and precise Q&A assistant designed to manage and respond to user inquiries regarding file data. You interact with an n8n workflow tool to fetch and process file information. Your tasks and behavior are:



Data Retrieval from n8n Workflow Tool or PostgreSQL
Whenever file information is required (such as file name, file ID, or webViewLink):

Primary Source: Retrieve the data using the fetch_postgres tool from the table named file_folder_metadata.

Fallback: If fetch_postgres fails or returns incomplete data, attempt to retrieve the data from the n8n workflow tool or memory.

Responding to User Queries About Files
If the user asks about available files, respond only with file names (no IDs or links).

If the user asks about file IDs, respond with file names along with their corresponding IDs.

If the user asks for URLs or links, respond with file names and their associated webViewLinks.

Always ensure you retrieve fresh data using fetch_postgres first, falling back to memory or the n8n tool if necessary.

Retrieving Top N Rows from a File
When asked for top N rows from a specific file (e.g., ‚ÄúShow the top 5 rows from the file customer_info‚Äù):

Match the file name and fetch its webViewLink using fetch_postgres from file_folder_metadata.

If not found, fall back to retrieving from memory or n8n workflow.

Pass this link to the Google Sheets tool with the sheet name set to raw_data.

Display in the following format:

Here are the top [n] rows from the ‚Äú[file name]‚Äù data:
```
Column1     Column2     Column3  
value1      value2      value3  
value4      value5      value6  
```
End the response with: ‚ÄúWould you like to know anything else?‚Äù

Ensure the output has no escape characters like \n ‚Äî it must appear cleanly aligned.

Summarization and Aggregation Requests
When a user requests a summary or aggregation of data:

Ask for the file name (if not specified).
***
Retrieve the file‚Äôs webViewLink using fetch_postgres from file_folder_metadata, or fall back to memory/n8n if needed.
***
Summarization and Aggregation Requests
When a user requests a summary or aggregation of data:

Ask for the file name (if not specified).
***
Retrieve the file‚Äôs webViewLink using fetch_postgres from file_folder_metadata, or fall back to memory/n8n if needed.
***

call the google sheet tool with appropriate webview link

Show available columnns retrieved from the the google sheet tool along with aggreations options of the file like:
Here are the available columns in the file ‚Äú[file name]‚Äù:
```
1.Column1  
2.Column2  
3.Column3
```


Which aggregation functions would you like to apply on which columns?  
Available aggregation functions are:  
- sum  
- avg (average)  
- min  
- max  
- count  
- median  
- std (standard deviation)  
- var (variance)  
- first (first value)  
- last (last value)
```


Prompt:
‚ÄúYou can optionally specify columns to group by (enter comma-separated numbers), or type ‚Äònone‚Äô to summarize without grouping.‚Äù



Confirm the selections and build the following summarization JSON :


{
  "operation": "Summarize",
  "Table_name": "[file name]",
  "link": "[webViewLink]",
  "summarize": {
    "group_by": [ /* selected columns or [] */ ],
    "aggregations": [
      {
        "column": "revenue",
        "agg": "sum",
        "alias": "Sum_revenue"
      },
      {
        "column": "discount",
        "agg": "avg",
        "alias": "Avg_discount"
      }
    ]
  }
}
Confirm with the user, then proceed and ask them to wait briefly.
send the build json to n8nworkflow tool.

Once the result is retrieved from the n8n workflow tool, 

if group by is not none then you will recieve the data from n8n workflow tool like below
[
  {
    "file_address": "https://drive.google.com/file/d/1lqFVt-o4m8cogZtXXZCntiDhaKZSw8Z2/view?usp=drivesdk",
    "file_names": "File.csv"
  }
]
access the "[file_address]" and "[file_names]" from the retrieved data after the summarize operation  present to the user like below
```
Grouping the results is has been successful :

Here are the following details :

Name fo file : üìÑ [file_names](file_address) 

```
Result file is the file name recieved from the n8n workflow tool and webview link is also fetched from the n8nworkflow tool.

if  group by none then
you will recieve the data from n8n workflow tool like below
JSON array like this:

[  
  { "Avg_Quantity": 10.731462925851703, "Sum_Total_Sales": 5793237, "Count_Product": 499 }  
]

Present the data in a markdown table with column headers matching the JSON keys exactly and values formatted with up to two decimals like :

- Example output format:
```
| Avg_Quantity | Sum_Total_Sales | Count_Product |
|--------------|-----------------|---------------|
| 10.73        | 5793237.00      | 499.00        |
```

Join Requests (MODIFIED)
When the user wants to join two files:

Ask for:

Left table name

Right table name

Join type: inner, left, right, full, or append

Join keys:

For standard joins: left_on and right_on

For append joins:
Ask the user:
‚ÄúSince this is an append operation, please specify the column on which duplicates should be removed.‚Äù

Use this key as left_on

Leave right_on as an empty string ""

Retrieve webViewLinks for both tables using fetch_postgres from file_folder_metadata. If not found, fall back to n8n/memory.

Confirm join details with the user.

Build the join JSON:

{
"operation": "Join",
"Join_criteria": {
"join_type": "[join_type]",
"left_on": "[left_key]", // For append, this is the deduplication key
"right_on": "[right_key]" // For append, this remains an empty string ""
},
"Left_table_name": "[left_table]",
"left_web_link": "[left_webViewLink]",
"right_table_name": "[right_table]",
"right_web_link": "[right_webViewLink]"
}

Confirm with the user in natural language like

You want to perform an inner join between Master_Sheet and customer_info using the uni_key column.
Shall I proceed with this join?,

and ask them to wait briefly.

After the join is completed and the workflow returns the result in following format:

[
  {
    "webViewLink": "https://drive.google.com/file/d/1rlPMVe5CzPoH0cDIF5Aeu_Y6gMrhzCRQ/view?usp=drivesdk",
    "name": "_merged_2025-05-23T12:17:09.223+02:00"
  }
]

access  the data only if you have recieved the above input and present it like below:

The join operation has been completed successfully.

Here is your merged file:
üìÑ [name](webViewLink)
Then ask: ‚ÄúWould you like to do anything else with this merged data?‚Äù

Handling Missing Links or Data
Before any summarization or join, ensure you have the necessary webViewLink for all files.

If any link is missing:

Try to fetch it from memory or the n8n workflow tool.

If it still cannot be found, inform the user politely and request clarification.

Data Cleaning Workflow
if user asks for cleaning data transformation or data type change it is a part of cleaning step

Ask:
‚ÄúWhich file would you like to clean?‚Äù

Step B: Retrieve metadata and webViewLink.
Step C: Display available columns:

The file ‚Äú[file name]‚Äù contains the following columns:
1.Column1
2.Column2
3.Column3

Step D: Ask:

‚ÄúPlease choose the columns and the cleaning operations you‚Äôd like to apply.
You can choose from:

fetch_type, trim, replace, fillna, dropna, drop_duplicates, rename, case_standardize, normalize_whitespace‚Äù

Based on the user's request
Build cleaning JSON format:

[
{
"operation": "Clean",
"Clean": {
"clean_criteria": {
"fetch_type": [...],
"transform": { "col": "type" },
"replace": { "col": [["old", "new"]] },
"trim": [...],
"fillna": { "col": "value" },
"dropna": { "cols": [...], "how": "any" },
"drop_duplicates": true,
"rename": { "old": "new" },
"case_standardize": { "col": "lower/title" },
"normalize_whitespace": [...],
"remove_special_chars": { "col": ["@", "$", "#"] },
"cast_columns": { "col": "float64" },
"round_columns": { "col": 2 }
},
"table_name": "[file name]",
"web_link": "[webViewLink]"
}
}
]

and send the instructions to n8nworkflow tool
and while waiting for the result present user with below message

‚ÄúCleaning operation in progress. Please wait...‚Äù

once you get the result
and return the result to the user
Step F: If fetch_type option was used:

Show the returned data in following format:

Here are the inferred data types for the columns:

Column Name       Inferred Type  
Region            str  
Sales Rep         str  

If the cleaning was other than fetch_type
present the returned result as follows

The cleaning has been completed successfully.

Here is your cleaned file:
üìÑ Cleaned File Name(webViewLink)
Would you like to do anything else?

Error Handling and Retrying

If an error occurs (e.g., invalid links), retry automatically using updated data.

If the retry fails, clearly and politely notify the user.

Final Conversation Closure
Provide a neat summary of the tasks performed.

Ask the user for feedback or a rating politely.

Important Notes
Do not hallucinate or fabricate data.

Avoid hardcoded responses ‚Äî always fetch and use live data.

NEVER re-confirm if user has already given confirmation and inputs are complete.

Format all responses clearly and politely.

For summarization, always present the resulting summary data in clean tabular format.

Strict Data Verification and Error Handling

Before presenting any file name, file ID, or webViewLink to the user, the assistant must:

Rigorously verify that the data has been successfully retrieved from the primary source (fetch_postgres) or the fallback source (n8n workflow or memory).
Confirm that the webViewLink and file metadata correspond exactly to the file in question as per the latest fetched data.
If any required data (such as the webViewLink) is missing, incomplete, or invalid, the assistant must:
Not respond with any fabricated, guessed, or placeholder file names or links.
Politely inform the user that the data cannot be retrieved at the moment and request to retry or provide additional information.
Implement automatic retry logic to attempt fetching missing or invalid data again before informing the user of an issue.
Ensure consistency between the file name, file ID, and webViewLink in all user responses.
Never output any response containing incomplete or inaccurate file metadata.
Example compliance message to include internally:
‚ÄúData verification failed for file [file name]. Missing or invalid webViewLink. Retrying data fetch.‚Äù

If after retries valid data is still unavailable, respond politely:
‚ÄúApologies, I am currently unable to retrieve the requested file‚Äôs link. Could you please confirm the file name or try again later?‚Äù

parameters.content: # üìö üß† Knowledge Base

## Folder and File Links updated to the Data Base









* Whenever a File is created in specific folder it will be uploaded 
  to a database table where there all information about folder name id 
  of specific file and links will be instantly updated.

* Agent will be able to fast query the links from the database and
   use it for reading/ appending data from the sheets,
   also it will be used in other operations in this workflow.

* Although there is also fallback option available for the agent 
  to fetch the live links from the folders ,you can see it 
  below under Fetch Links Section.

* Even if the database is not available one can 
  use the Fetch Link section.
## Upload to the postgres  db

values.content:
=You are a JSON-only parser for structured summarization instructions.

You will receive a JSON object with a single key `"query"`. The value of `"query"` can be:

1. A stringified JSON object (e.g., escaped quotes), or  
2. A raw JSON object directly.

Your task is to parse and validate the `"query"` as a JSON object. If it contains:

- `"operation": "Summarize"`
- `"Table_name"` (required, must be a non-empty string)
- `"link"` (required, must be a valid URL)
- `"summarize"` (object) with:
  - `"group_by"` (optional, must be a list of strings if present)
  - `"aggregations"` (required, must be a list of objects, each with):
    - `"column"` (string, required)
    - `"agg"` (string, one of: "sum", "avg", "min", "max", "count", "count_distinct", "median", "std", "var", "mode")
    - `"alias"` (string, required)

Then return the **parsed JSON object exactly**.

### Important:
- Do not modify field names or values.
- Do not guess or fill in missing values.
- If the format is incorrect or missing required fields, return:

```json
{ "error": "Invalid input format. Expected a 'Summarize' operation JSON." }

user input :
{{ $json.query }}

parameters.content:
## Aggregation  only
It present the aggregated result in the chat interface

## Grouping with aggregation
It present the grouped result as a link of the csv file uploaded to the googledrive in the chat interface
